Thoughts / criticisms / improvements most appreciated.

stories.text:
Both Facebook and Craigslist automatically censors any rental listing with a gender/sex keyword.

I am not even allowed to describe the sex of the other tenant who is already living in the suite. It's a machine algorithm block, they don't even need other users to flag the posting. It's an automatically ban.

Does any person think the wording below is prohibitive or discriminating?

> We are renting out one room in a 2-bedroom basement suite. The suite has two rooms. One room is already rented by a university male student. We are looking for a responsible and respectful tenant to rent the other room. This is ideal for a student or a young professional individual.

I confirm that the offensive word above is male. Once I remove it. the posting is ok.

My question is what algorithm Facebook and Craigslist use to flag and block posting. what's the reason that they would flag a posting like this?
stories.title: What algorithm Facebook and Craigslist use to flag posting?

stories.text: I'm working on a small SaaS site, both as an earnest attempt to create some income for myself and as an attempt to teach myself programming. At it's core it involves scraping data from various places on the web, combining it, cleaning it, and laying it out in a useful way. I have made progress on my own, but I know I would make more progress if I had someone with experience helping me out. I don't have the capital to hire someone to do it, nor do I want to just hire someone. The point is that even if this business doesn't succeed, I will come away with a lot more knowledge on web development, site administration, and scraping and cleaning data. As an alternative to hiring someone to build the site, I'm wondering about hiring a tutor to help me move forward faster. It seems to me that there would be ethical and business problems that arise from this. Wouldn't my tutor in a way be an employee? How could I protect the business idea while getting help from the tutor? I suppose one alternative would be signing a non-disclosure agreement and offering a certain amount of equity or revenue sharing. I am not out here to exploit someone else's work and pass it off as my own. I want to build the service, run it, and maintain it, but I know that I would benefit from having more experienced eyes guiding me in my work. I'm hoping someone on here could offer some advice, ideas, or alternatives.
stories.title: Receiving Tutoring on a For-Profit Project
